docs.lead_paragraph: The House passed a bill changing the definition of the workweek from 30 hours to 40 hours, which proponents say would save businesses with 50 or more employees from having to make cuts in other parts of their businesses to pay for health care coverage.

headline.main: House Fires Shot at Health Care Law, Seeking to Alter Critical Coverage Rule
headline.print_headline: House Fires Shot at Health Care Law, Seeking to Alter Critical Coverage Rule

docs.abstract: House passes bill altering definition of full-time worker under Affordable Care Act from one who works 30 hours per week, to one who works 40 hours; Republicans contend measure will stop businesses with 50 or more employees from cutting worker hours to avoid mandatory health insurance; measure is seen as symbol for Republican efforts to undermine Pres Obama's signature health care act.
docs.snippet: The House passed a bill changing the definition of the workweek from 30 hours to 40 hours, which proponents say would save businesses with 50 or more employees from having to make cuts in other parts of their businesses to pay for health care...

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders in the Republican Party seem to be wrong on everything that counts, but no amount of contrary evidence will get them to change their minds.
docs.abstract: Paul Krugman Op-Ed column deplores Congressional Republicans for taking credit for sharp increase in American economic growth, while data shows that growth began before they took control of Congress; faults Republicans for frequently ignoring evidence and cooking up conspiracy theories in order to support its version of truth; contends Congress is controlled by members who never acknowledge error or learn from their mistakes.
docs.snippet: Leaders in the Republican Party seem to be wrong on everything that counts, but no amount of contrary evidence will get them to change their minds.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: They cost the country billions, but they don’t save lives.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by oncologist Ezekiel J Emanuel encourages Americans to skip their annual physical, contending that such exams are essentially worthless; cites data showing that annual health exams do little to reduce mortality rates, or even to catch potential health threats; adds that exams cost country billions of dollars and in some cases may even hurt patients.
docs.snippet: They cost the country billions, but they don’t save lives.

docs.lead_paragraph: The store in Akron, Ohio, became known as “the Ebola store” after a Dallas nurse who had visited later tested positive for the virus.

headline.main: Stigma of Ebola Customer Is Too Much for Bridal Shop
headline.print_headline: Stigma of Ebola Customer Is Too Much for Bridal Shop

docs.abstract: Coming Attractions bridal shop in Akron, Ohio, closes after failing to shake its reputation as 'the Ebola store' after Dallas nurse Amber Joy Vinson, who had visited store, later tested positive for deadly virus.

headline.main: House Passes Bill to Alter Health Law's Workweek Provision

docs.abstract: The 114th Congress took up its first bill to impose changes to the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, with the House of Representatives passing legislation to expand the definition of a workweek to 40 hours, from 30.
docs.snippet: The 114th Congress took up its first bill to impose changes to the Affordable Care Act on Thursday, with the House of Representatives passing legislation to expand the definition of a workweek to 40 hours, from 30.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives voted on Thursday to ease Obamacare's health insurance requirements for employers by approving the first of an expected series of bills aimed at weakening the overall healthcare reform law.

headline.main: U.S. House Votes to Ease Obamacare Employer Requirements
headline.print_headline: U.S. House Votes to Ease Obamacare Employer Requirements

docs.snippet: The Republican-led U.S. House of Representatives voted on Thursday to ease Obamacare's health insurance requirements for employers by approving the first of an expected series of bills aimed at weakening the overall healthcare reform law.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican-led House has approved a bill reducing the number of workers who must be offered employer-provided health insurance under President Barack Obama's health care law.
